sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'
  import { MDXTag } from '@mdx-js/tag'
  

export default class MDXContent extends React.Component {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props)
    this.layout = null
  }
  render() {
    const { components, ...props } = this.props

    return <MDXTag
             name="wrapper"
             
             components={components}><MDXTag name="h1" components={components} props={{"id":"eks-in-depth"}}>{`EKS in Depth`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`This is more of a basic theory section to understand how EKS works.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"pricing"}}>{`Pricing`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`USD\$0.20 per hours for each EKS cluster you make. That's ~USD\$144/month.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`You pay normally for all the other resources related to running your apps:`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Worker nodes (EC2)`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`EBS volumes`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Network traffic`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Load balancers`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Check online for if pricing ever changes.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"eks-control-place"}}>{`EKS Control Place`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`The control plane sets up the cluster to be highly available (in 3 availability zones).`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Each AZ will have a master node and etcd that is AWS managed. The workers nodes are what we supply.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Our local `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`kubectl`}</MDXTag>{` will talk directly to EKS.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h3" components={components} props={{"id":"under-the-hood"}}>{`Under the hood`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}><MDXTag name="img" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"src":"https://res.cloudinary.com/gitgoodclub/image/upload/v1548213794/eks-course/Screen_Shot_2019-01-23_at_2.22.40_pm.png","alt":"Under the hood"}}></MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Single tenant (you do not share it with other customers)`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Made of native AWS component (EC2, ELB, ASG, NLB, VPC)`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"eks-networking"}}>{`EKS Networking`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}><MDXTag name="img" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"src":"https://res.cloudinary.com/gitgoodclub/image/upload/v1548213958/eks-course/Screen_Shot_2019-01-23_at_2.25.49_pm.png","alt":"Network"}}></MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Recommended to have:`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ol" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ol">{`Private subnets: containers all the worker nodes to have application deployed. Must be large CIDR.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ol">{`Public subnets: Will contain any internet-facing load balancer to expose the applications.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ol">{`The VPC must have DNS hostname and DNS resolution support, otherwise nodes can't register.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h3" components={components} props={{"id":"security-groups"}}>{`Security groups`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}><MDXTag name="img" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"src":"https://res.cloudinary.com/gitgoodclub/image/upload/v1548214249/eks-course/Screen_Shot_2019-01-23_at_2.30.35_pm.png","alt":"Security groups explored"}}></MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`You have 2 security groups: `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`Control Plane`}</MDXTag>{` and `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`Worker Nodes`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Read up on `}<MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"href":"https://github.com/freach/kubernetes-security-best-practice"}}>{`https://github.com/freach/kubernetes-security-best-practice`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h3" components={components} props={{"id":"eks-pod-networking"}}>{`EKS Pod Networking`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Amazon VPC CNI plugin: each pod receivers 1 IP address (=ENI => Elastic Network Interface) in VPC.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Pods have the same IP address inside the EKS cluster and outside of it.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Subnet limitations: CIRD /24 is 254 IP, not enough to run a lot of pods. You'll need a way bigger CIDR. Recommended is a CIDR /18.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`EC2 limitations: limited to amount of ENI/IP addresses it can have. Based on the network types, AWS has documentation on EC2 limits for ENIs, IPv4s and IPv6s.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`See `}<MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"href":"https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-eni.html"}}>{`https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-eni.html`}</MDXTag>{` for more information on ENI limits.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h3" components={components} props={{"id":"network-security-with-calico"}}>{`Network security with Calico`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Security groups allow all worker nodes to communicate to each other on any ports.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`This may be a problem if you want to segement applications, tenants or environments.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`You can use the Calico project instead of AWS Security Groups in this case.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Network policies are directly assigned to pods (instead of worker nodes).`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`More granular.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h3" components={components} props={{"id":"iam-and-rbac-integration"}}>{`IAM and RBAC Integration`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}><MDXTag name="img" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"src":"https://res.cloudinary.com/gitgoodclub/image/upload/v1548215421/eks-course/Screen_Shot_2019-01-23_at_2.50.02_pm.png","alt":"IAM and RBAC in action"}}></MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Note: RBAC means "Role-Based-Access-Control".`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`When you talk to Kubernetes, authentication is held by IAM.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Authorization is done by Kubernetes RBAC (native auth for K8s).`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Done through collaboration between AWS and Heptio.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`You can assign RBAC directly through IAM entities.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`By default, the role you assign to your K8s cluster has system:master permissions.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h3" components={components} props={{"id":"k8s-worker-nodes"}}>{`K8s Worker Nodes`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}><MDXTag name="img" components={components} parentName="p" props={{"src":"https://res.cloudinary.com/gitgoodclub/image/upload/v1548216415/eks-course/Screen_Shot_2019-01-23_at_3.06.44_pm.png","alt":"K8s Worker Nodes"}}></MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`When the join the cluster, they are assigned an IAM role and authorized in RBAC to join `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`system:bootstrappers`}</MDXTag>{` and `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`system: nodes`}</MDXTag>{` in your ConfigMap.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`You can write your own rules in the ConfigMap.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h3" components={components} props={{"id":"eks-load-balancers"}}>{`EKS Load Balancers`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`EKS support `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`Classic Load Balancer`}</MDXTag>{`, `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`Application Load Balancer`}</MDXTag>{` and `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`Network Load Balancer`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Classic and Network Load Balancer is for Service of type `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`LoadBalancer`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Application Load Balancer is for Ingress Controller.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h3" components={components} props={{"id":"loadbalancer"}}>{`LoadBalancer`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Through the service of type `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`LoadBalancer`}</MDXTag>{`, EKS will create a:`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Classic Load Balancer by default.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Netword Load Balancer if this is specified: `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`service.beta.kubernetes.io/aws-load-balancer-type:nlb`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`There is also support for internal load balancers: `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`service.beta.kubernetes.io//aws-load-balancer-internal:0.0.0.0/0`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`You can control the configuration of LBs using annotations in your manifest.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`All documentation for `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="li">{`LoadBalancer`}</MDXTag>{` on AWS is diretly on the Kubernetes project.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`ALB Ingress is open source and found on GitHub.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Supports target group of instance mode (hooked into NodePort).`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Supports target group of IP mode (directly communicating with the pod).`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Supports Application Load Balancer listener rules.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
           </MDXTag>
  }
}
